name: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Double Agent®
description: The best-selling Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell® saga takes on an entirely new direction. In the highly anticipated sequel to the 2005 game of the year, Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Double Agent™, play as a double agent spy for the first time ever.

reviews.review_text: [4/10]  As much as I'd love to finish this game, I don't think it will even let me. The game crashes almost every mission for no reason, quick saves will randomly decide to not load, the entire game just freezes during certain loading screens. Also, the game looks awful compared to previous games in the Splinter Cell franchise, which is odd, considering Chaos Theory was absolutely gorgeous for its time, and still holds up to this day. Sometimes shadows won't even render when the level loads, making the whole stealth mechanic extremely awkward. Being a huge fan of Splinter Cell, it's really unfortunate that this game is unstable, to the point of freezing my computer. I could only recommend this game to hardcore fans of the Splinter Cell franchise. I will attempt to finish this game, and if it gets better, I will edit this review. Until then, this still stands.  [EDIT] So I've finished the game. The bugs and glitches are still present, no suprise there, but there was one specific bug that stood out amongst others: a game breaking bug. After completing the final mission, a cutscene is supposed to play, the credits should roll, and you are rewarded with a bonus mission. For me, and many others, this didn't happen. The mission would end, and then cut immediately to an overhead scene of the level where you are unable to move and unable to quit properly. (you have to enter the Task Manager and end it manually.) Aside from the awful technical issues, the gameplay and story are some of the best in the Splinter Cell series so far. It takes place shortly after the events of Chaos Theory, in which Sam must pose as a criminal and join a terrorist force in order to destroy them from the inside. The game has a 'trust meter,' in which you have to complete objectives for the JBA: the terrorist force, and the NSA: the good guys. Due to trust being a factor, the game forces you to enter in these moral gray areas just to keep the trust of the enemy. While in the base, you have the option to research and spy on your allies/enemies to learn more info about them. This information will assist you in traversing the base as well as unlock special items for your missions. As with all previous games in the franchise, it is all based on stealth and using gadgets as well as the enviornment to your advantage to accomplish your objectives. If you've played a SC game in the past, you know what you're getting yourself into from a gameplay perspective.   Summary: Splinter Cell: Double Agent is a fantastic game form a gameplay and story perspecrive, but it is hindered by so many techinical issues that it is not worth the purchase, at least not on the PC. I have heard that the concole version is much better, so if you would like to play this game, play it on the Xbox, PS2, or PS3.

Nice otherwise (after ini-file edit to enable better graphics), but loading the save games didn't work for me at all. And this game crashes alot, so frustation level can be high especially when the save games won't work and you have to start beginning of the mission sometimes.  I also heard that the best version was only for PS2/Gamecube/Xbox. So if you happen to own one of those systems, might be better option to pick that up instead of this.  Oh, and if you run into a bug before the credits roll, change the game resolution to lower like 1024x768 and the ending will trigger.

Besides being a terrible PC port with crashes, glitches, long loading times, bad performance and requiring you to actually manually download a patch, this game feels very incomplete (it's the 360 version after all) leaving many plot and character development holes, a morality system that barely does anything, and a terrible ending which is just audio over the credits. It's a very unsatisfying game. If you really want to play Double Agent, get the PS2/Xbox/Gamecube version, which was made by the Chaos Theory devs and it actually feels complete. Also you never get dubs in this game. Not recommended.

6 out of 10  This is the 4th episode in the Splinter Cell series. You play as Sam Fisher, an operative in 3rd Echelon a top secret NSA black-op outfit. Its all about stealth, not so much on killing.  If you haven't played any Splinter Cell game yet, what? Where have you been. These are great games. However, you should not start with SC Double Agent.  This game is for SC veterans who want to do it all. I started on this game three times. Only the last time did I bite the bullet and stuck through. Unfortunately compared to the previous SC games this one is slightly disappointing.   The good:  1. Decent stealth based action. Shooting is not what its about and the shooting system has never been a strong point in any SC game - it is very static.   The bad:  2. Where is the luminosity meter? Knowing when shadows are enough to cover you is a guessing game.  3. The choices you make have no discernable impact on the game. Only the cut-scenes.  4. What is the story all about? Some people want to blow up the USA, but why?  5. The characters are as thin as wet paper. Sam's daughter is killed off at the start, why?  6. You unlock lots of equipment. When do you actually get to use it?   The ugly:  7. Horrible stability issues. My game crashed about five times per mission.  8. Character model getting stuck in the scenery.   Dam, in retrospect there where not many good points. Thank goodness the game is relatively short.
